headline: Homemade Chick-fil-A Sandwiches Recipe
description: A spot-on copycat recipe for Chick-fil-A's famous fried chicken breast sandwich, complete with two pickles.
name: Homemade Chick-fil-A Sandwiches Recipe
keywords: chick-fil-a, chicken, chicken breast, chicken sandwiches, fast food, fried chicken, sandwich, The Food Lab
recipeIngredient: 1/2 cup plus 1/2 teaspoon (123g) kosher salt, divided (see note)
1/4 cup plus 2 teaspoons (58g) granulated sugar, divided
2 large boneless skinless chicken breasts, split horizontally into 4 cutlets
4 soft hamburger buns, toasted in butter

recipeInstructions.text: Dissolve 1/2 cup (120g) kosher salt (see note) and 1/4 cup (50g) sugar in 1 quart (950ml) of cold water. Place chicken breasts in a zipper-lock bag and add brine. Transfer to refrigerator and let sit no longer than 6 hours.
Meanwhile, combine black pepper, paprika, MSG (if using), and cayenne in a small bowl. Set aside.
Whisk together milk and eggs in a medium bowl. Set aside.

Combine flour, non-fat milk powder, baking powder, remaining 1/2 teaspoon (3g) kosher salt, remaining 2 teaspoons (8g) sugar, and 2 tablespoons of spice mixture in a large bowl and whisk until homogenous. Drizzle 3 tablespoons (45ml) milk-egg mixture into flour mixture and rub with fingertips until the flour mixture is coarse like wet sand.
In a large wok, deep fryer, or Dutch oven, preheat oil to 350째F (177째C).

Remove chicken breasts from brine and pat dry with paper towels. Season on all sides with remaining spice mixture. Transfer to milk mixture and turn to coat. Working one cutlet at a time, allow excess milk mixture to drip off then transfer to flour mixture. Turn to coat, pile extra mixture on top of cutlet, and press down firmly to adhere as much mixture as possible to the meat. Lift cutlet, shake off excess flour, then slowly lower into hot oil. Repeat with remaining breasts.
Cook, turning breasts occasionally until golden brown and crisp on all sides, and chicken is cooked through, about 4 minutes total. Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate.

Place 2 pickles on each bottom bun and a fried chicken cutlet on top. Close sandwiches, then cover with an overturned bowl or aluminum foil and allow to rest for 2 minutes to steam buns. Serve immediately.

review.reviewBody: @i8thecat I have not edited or deleted any comments related to MSG, and I have no problem defending myself without resorting to deleting comments that make me look bad. Perhaps you are talking about your comments in the main post in which you ask "How incredibly stupid are you?" with a few extra question marks. I didn't delete that comment, but I didn't respond to it because I don't make a habit of giving folks who come at me in that sort of disrespectful tone the time of day. I'm civil to you, If you would like me to address your questions or engage in a debate, you've got to be civil to me. It's simple manners. Thanks.

Just jumping on to remind everyone to do proper research before spreading outdated theories, and that MSG does not, in fact, ruin people's brains — and is also listed as an optional ingredient, so why complain about it to begin with?

I have made these several times and want to love them but they are so salty they leave my mouth puckered for hours after eating them. Today I only brined them for an hour, rinsed them before putting the seasoning on and I completely left the salt out of the spice mixture. They were still too salty. I use diamond crystal kosher salt. I am a seasoned cook and I tend to have a heavy hand with salt sometimes. It is rare when something taste too salty to me. Since I have already cut out the salt in the seasoning mixture, how can I adjust the brine to be less salty but still work property on the texture? I know there has to be a proper proportion of salt to sugar to water, just don't know what it is. These have so much potential but they are way salter than the CFL.

I made this tonight with a couple of variations - since we wanted to have it tonight, I didn't brine the chicken. I want to do that next time, but it wasn't in the cards tonight. It was still good, though. I also took a suggestion from another commentator and baked it. That caused a problem of the outermost breading to stay dry and need to be scraped off. Since it was just my husband and me at home, this wasn't a big issue, but it's something to be aware of if you're planning to make it for someone you want to impress. I didn't use any MSG since I just didn't have any and didn't feel like going in search of it, as I doubt I'd use it much anyway. 

I wish people would take the arguments somewhere else. Recipes are supposed to be the one place where it's safe to read the bottom half of the Internet. If you have a personal preference not to use an ingredient, that's fine. Just leave it at that. Go start your own blog to tout the evils of it, but for those of us who look at comments for things like "you can bake it instead of frying," or "I substituted this and it didn't work," it's annoying to find trolls and instigators.
